title: How Women Took Ownership of Their Bodies in 2020
meta_title: How Women Took Ownership of Their Bodies in 2020
description: In a year when women's rights were threatened, women in entertainment reclaimed their power and sexuality. From "Wap" to "I May Destroy You."

The death of Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg and her replacement with conservative justice Amy Coney Barrett jeopardizes the future of Roe v. Wade. A SCOTUS ruling made it harder for women to access birth control under employers who oppose contraceptives. And some states used COVID-19 as an excuse to ban abortion procedures.In the same year, calls for decriminalizing sex work became more fervent, heightening the importance of women, trans, and nonbinary individuals making their own sexual decisions. The trade has resulted in the arrest and abuse of nearly 40 percent of Black and multiracial, trans-identifying individuals who participate. Although an estimated one million Americans are reliant on it to survive, a misogynistic stigma keeps us from making substantial change. But this increase in advocacy proves that there’s a public desire to defend one’s sexual freedom.But while societal and governmental attempts to suppress women's rights and police their bodies continue in real life, artists responded by expressing femininity and sexuality in pop culture and on screens, big and small. It’s refreshing and important to see women reclaiming their power in the music, television, and film industries, where themes of equality, choice, consent, pleasure, and accountability thrive. This year, songs like “WAP,” shows like I May Destroy You, and films like Never Rarely Sometimes Always have provided radical sociopolitical commentary, forcing people to listen, watch, and make necessary changes.Cardi B and Megan Thee Stallion break boundaries with "WAP."View full post on YoutubeThe chart-topping, jaw-dropping anthem “WAP” by Cardi B and Megan Thee Stallion, in which the ladies trade bars about what they require in the bedroom, became a cultural behemoth this summer. Despite countless rap songs throughout history by women and men alike discussing their down and dirty sexual desires, “WAP” is in a class of its own, taking an overt approach that leaves nothing to the imagination right out of the gate. (“Beat it up, n***a, catch a charge / Extra large and extra hard,” Cardi demands.)Other hip-hop and R&B stars like City Girls and Doja Cat, Mulatto, and Jhené Aiko also released tracks boasting their sexual power in 2020 (“Pu$$y Talk,” “On God,” and “Pussy Fairy (OTW),” respectively). On her turn as “B” in the “Savage” remix, Beyoncé spits a bar about OnlyFans, a subscription-based service website praised by Assistant Professor of Sociology at Hollins University Jennifer Turner “as a means for women to own their sexuality, to make a living, to supplement their income, and so forth.” Black women’s loud and proud ownership of their bodies may be threatening to some, but women on the mic couldn’t care less. This year, pleasure won over politeness.Ariana Grande releases 'positions' and Dua Lipa calls out double standards.View full post on YoutubeOutside of the rap sector, Ariana Grande displayed her sexual power and liberation in her latest album, positions, with tracks like the innuendo-filled “34+35,” and the straightforward “nasty.” Dua Lipa’s Grammy-nominated LP Future Nostalgia features tunes such as the bouncy romp “Good in Bed” and the emphatic “Boys Will Be Boys,” which shows the double standards between men and women when it comes to topics ranging from self-sufficiency to street harassment. (“We hide our figures, doing anything to shut their mouths,” she sings, adding, “We smile away to ease the tension, so it don’t go south.”) As leaders of pop music’s new school, Grande taking a firm hold of her sexuality and Lipa calling out society’s shortcomings empowers listeners to do the same.Fiona Apple speaks up for sexual assault survivors on "For Her."View full post on YoutubeOn the rage-filled "For Her," a track from Fiona Apple's critically acclaimed Fetch the Bolt Cutters, the singer-songwriter speaks for those who know what it’s like to not have control of their bodies. Inspired by Brett Kavanaugh's confirmation to the Supreme Court, Apple shares the harrowing experiences of a fellow survivor who’s unable to tell her story. Apple told The New Yorker that her album is about “not being afraid to speak,” and in this track, she tells the truth for people who might not be ready to say it themselves.Advertisement - Continue Reading BelowP-Valley celebrates the female gaze. Jessica MiglioWhen it comes to sexual empowerment, the first season of Starz’s P-Valley provided audiences with a peek into the world of Southern strip clubs through the female gaze. Created by Katori Hall, the series bucked stereotypes, celebrating Black, female physical power. Each episode was directed by a woman and shot in a way that captures the sheer strength and sexuality of the dancers down at The Pynk, the series’ central strip club, without objectifying them. Through powerful storylines, the personal and professional lives of these working women prove that there is more to these establishments than meets the eye, setting a new precedent for how women’s stories can be portrayed.I May Destroy You dissects rape culture.HBOScreenwriter and actress Michaela Coel transformed her experience with sexual assault into an empathetic journey to healing with her HBO drama, I May Destroy You. The series centers on Arabella, played by Coel, who attempts to put the pieces of her foggy memory together after being drugged and raped during a night out. “The whole show deals with that moment where consent was stolen from you and you lost the moment where you had agency to make a decision,” Coel told BBC News. “We need to be kinder to ourselves a bit more and forgive ourselves for the times when we didn’t say no loud enough.” I May Destroy You proves it’s integral that those who have been hurt grant themselves peace—that healing takes time and self-forgiveness.Mrs. America includes Gloria Steinem's abortion. FX/HuluFX and Hulu’s Mrs. America explored bodily agency through the lens of reproductive freedom while highlighting the movements surrounding the passing of the Equal Rights Amendment in 1972. The second episode covered the real-life experience of feminist icon Gloria Steinem (portrayed by Rose Byrne) getting an illegal abortion at the age of 22, which fueled her decades-long advocacy for legal, safe access to the procedure.“How many more women are going to die from botched abortions while we wait for men to feel comfortable with us having control over our own bodies?” Byrne's Steinem asked in the episode, titled simply “Gloria.” Though it’s set in the 1970s, Mrs. America’s topical look at gender equality, choice, and even voting rights resonates strongly today.Advertisement - Continue Reading BelowPromising Young Woman challenges viewers to believe women. Merie Weismiller WallaceEmerald Fennell’s forthcoming Promising Young Woman picks apart rape culture with dark humor. Even the title cheekily references a high-profile sexual assault case; in 2016, Stanford swimmer-turned-convicted rapist Brock Turner was often referred to by the media as a “promising young man.”The film, which will have its major release on Christmas Day, follows a woman’s nonviolent vengeance on would-be sexual aggressors who try to take advantage of her when they believe she’s drunk. Fennell challenges her audience’s thoughts surrounding sexual misconduct allegations: Can accused assaulters be innocent if they’re “one of the good guys”? Is a woman ever “asking for it”? Promising Young Woman challenges the tendency to excuse deplorable behavior over believing women’s stories.Never Rarely Sometimes Always exposes the realities of abortion access.Angal FieldA woman’s power to choose is also explored in Never Rarely Sometimes Always, directed by Eliza Hittman. The Sundance Film Festival favorite follows pregnant Pennsylvanian teen Autumn as she travels to New York, to get an abortion without parental consent. Over the course of her trip, she muses about past choices and thinks about how her decision to get an abortion has the power to change her future.Hittman told Polygon that she wanted to speak directly to young women and explore the political issue of female autonomy through “an intimate lens.” By depicting Autumn’s long, emotional, and physical journey to obtain an abortion, the director reveals the many real-life challenges women must face to safely access the procedure, evoking empathy from viewers while also making the case for better abortion access.―Women in entertainment throughout 2020 proved that the radical power of autonomy and healing is revolutionary, and that empowerment, awareness, and acceptance is possible. While shows, songs, and movies highlighted what is attainable when it comes to feminine freedom and agency, it’s important to take these examples and work toward making changes in ourselves, our communities, and our governments. Only then can we create a better future for women everywhere.J'na JeffersonJ’na Jefferson is a journalist and creative from Brooklyn by way of the Jersey Shore.
